standard: Land Use and Forestry - Afforestation and Reforestation

term_definitions.name: Tree
term_definitions.description: A tree is a perennial woody plant with one or several dominant sprouts that increase its circumference due to secondary growth. For a practical use of this document the definition of a tree in these requirements goes beyond the scientific definition of a tree and also includes shrubs, palms and bamboo plants. Differences in the context of specific requirements are noted on the individual pages. In any project, trees shall reach a minimum height of 2 meters. For forest inventories of these different types of trees, additional guidance is provided by the forest inventory guidelines in the BioCarbon Fund Sourcebook.

term_definitions.name: Forest
term_definitions.description: A forest is defined by the Designated National Authority (DNA) or equivalent entity of the project's host country. In case no forest definition is yet given by the DNA, the Project Developer can refer to the forest definition of the FAO or the national forest definition of the project's host country.

term_definitions.name: Wetland
term_definitions.description: Wetlands are lands that are transitional between terrestrial and aquatic systems where the water table is usually at or near the surface or the land is covered by shallow water, and that have one or more of these listed attributes.
attributes: At least periodically, the land supports predominantly hydrophytes.
The substrate is predominantly undrained hydric soil.
The substrate is non-soil and is saturated with water or covered by shallow water at some time during the growing season of each year.

term_definitions.name: Organic Soil
term_definitions.description: Organic soils fulfil at least one of these attributes.
attributes: If the soil is never saturated with water for more than a few days, and contains >20% (by weight) of organic carbon (35% organic matter).

If the soil is saturated with water for more than a few days at a time, and contains >12% (by weight) of organic carbon (20% organic matter) if no clay, or >18% (by weight) of organic carbon (30% organic matter) if it has >60% clay, or has a proportional lower limit of organic carbon content between 12 and 18% if the clay content of the minreal fraction is between 0 and 60%.

term_definitions.name: Selective Harvesting
term_definitions.description: Selective harvesting is done through the continuous harvest of single trees or groups of trees while maintaining forest on the area.

term_definitions.name: Planting
term_definitions.description: Planting refers to the activity of putting trees in the ground for growth; it also includes sowing or assisted natural regeneration.

term_definitions.name: Modelling Unit (MU)
term_definitions.description: Modelling Units are distinct parts of the planting area where carbon stocks can be quantified based on applying a forest growth-model. To meet the precision level for the carbon stocks estimation (see section CO2 removal), MU areas normally have homogeneous characteristics in their growth patterns, silvicultural treatment and planting date.

term_definitions.name: Significant
term_definitions.description: More than 5% of the 'long-term CO2 removal' - see section 'CO2 removal'.

term_definitions.name: CO2removal Project area, t
term_definitions.description: CO2-removal units of a project area in year t (tCO2)

term_definitions.name: CO2 removal MU,t
term_definitions.description: CO2-removal of a MU in year t (tCO2)

term_definitions.name: MUs
term_definitions.description: MUs of a project area (1, 2, 3, ...)

term_definitions.name: t
term_definitions.description: Years of the crediting period (1, 2, 3, ...)

term_definitions.name: CP
term_definitions.description: Year the crediting period ends (1, 2, 3, ...)

term_definitions.name: T
term_definitions.description: Number of years between the planting start and the end of the crediting period [ ]

term_definitions.name: CRMU,t
term_definitions.description: CO2 removal of a MU in year t [tCO2/ha]

term_definitions.name: CRMU,long_term
term_definitions.description: Long-term CO2-removal of a MU [tCO2/ha]

term_definitions.name: Leakage
term_definitions.description: Emissions that occur due to a shift of activities from the inside of a project area to the outside of a project area.

term_definitions.name: Area
term_definitions.description: Land within the project area where the activity is taking place.

term_definitions.name: % activity shift
term_definitions.description: Percentage of the activity that will be displaced during the crediting period, and will have impact on the 'tree biomass' outside the project area. The factor is determined by a credible estimations, or a representative survey.

term_definitions.name: CO2 Stock
term_definitions.description: Average stock of 'tree biomass' on the area where the activity will be displaced to. If it is not known where the activity will be displaced to, the CO2-stock = the average stock of 'tree biomass' of a natural forest in the projects host-country.

term_definitions.name: Displaced Heads
term_definitions.description: Amount of heads that will be displaced during the crediting period, and will have impact on the 'tree biomass' outside the project area. The factor is determined by a credible estimations, or a representative survey.

term_definitions.name: Grazing Capacity
term_definitions.description: Grazing capacity of the area where the livestock will be displaced to.

term_definitions.name: Other Emissions
term_definitions.description: Emissions that result from certain land preparation techniques, from the use of fertilisers and energy during project activities, and from nitrogen-fixing trees are categorized as 'Other Emissions'.

term_definitions.name: The Baseline
term_definitions.description: The Baseline is the estimated carbon stock that would occur in the baseline scenario. The baseline scenario describes the activities that would occur in the absence of the proposed project.

term_definitions.name: Conversion Procedure
term_definitions.description: How to convert from the unit of cubic meters [m3] or tonnes of dry matter [tdm] to tonnes of carbon [tC] and then to tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent [tCO2].

term_definitions.name: Wood Density
term_definitions.description: The woody density is the ratio between the mass of dry wood divided by its volume. Example: Wood density = Mass / Volume = 0.6 t / 1 m3 = 0.6 t / m3. Often the unit t (tonnes) is expressed as tdm (tonnes of dry matter).

term_definitions.name: Biomass Expansion Factor (BEF)
term_definitions.description: Aboveground tree biomass / Stem biomass. Example: BEF = Aboveground tree biomass / Stem biomass = 1.3 m3/ 1 m3 = 1.3. Some BEFs already include the Root-to-Shoot ratio.

term_definitions.name: Root to Shoot Ratio
term_definitions.description: Belowground tree biomass / Aboveground tree biomass. Root-to-Shoot ratio = Belowground tree biomass / Aboveground tree biomass = 0.3 m3/ 1.3 m3 = 0.23. Most Root-to-Shoot ratios are calculated from the Tree volume (including branches and leaves/needles), but some are based on the Stem volume.

term_definitions.name: Stem Volume
term_definitions.description: Based on a specific diameter of stump (x cm). The BEF should relate to this.

term_definitions.name: Ex ante
term_definitions.description: Ex ante means 'before the event'. In the context of carbon projects, ex ante refers to the period before the project starts.

state_nodes.description: This methodology comes into force on its publication date. The previous version of the methodology is valid until the attached date. The projects already submitted for listing or achieved listed status may continue with the previous version of methodology as long as the project is in compliance with applicable requirements of Emissions Reduction and Sequestration Product Requirements.
Project has been conceptualized.
Carry out spatial assessment of land to assess eligibility of areas according to our: Land-use & Forest General Requirements .
Project includes the planting of trees on land that does not meet the definition of forest.

dependencies.description: The project developer has completed the spatial assessment of land and deemed it eligible to apply for this methodology.

state_nodes.description: Project is not a mangrove project.
Is the project on a wetland?
Will project areas with organic soils be drained or irrigated (except for irrigation for planting)?

Will there be soil disturbance (through ploughing, digging of pits, stump removals, infrastructure, etc.) on organic soils exceeding more than 10% of the area that is submitted to certification (not 10% of the entire project area)?
Is the most likely scenario without the project (baseline scenario) defined and shows no significant increase of the baseline biomass ('tree' and 'non-tree')?
Project meets all non-mangrove requirements.
supporting_info: Project can apply all silvicultural systems: Conservation forests (no use of timber), Forests with selective harvesting, and Rotation forestry.
All projects can include agriculture (agroforestry) or pasture (silvopasture) activites.

state_nodes.description: Mangrove Project.
Is 90% or more of the planting area going to be planted with mangrove species?
Project meets all mangrove requirements.
supporting_info: Due to the accumulation of soil organic carbon, an additional 1.8 tCO2/ha/year can be accounted for in the first 20 years after a Modelling Unit is planted, unless transparent and verifiable information can be provided to justify a different value. This value is based on the recommendation of 0.5 tC/ha/year by the A/R CDM methodoology  AR-AM0014  v.30. It has been converted to the unit tCO2/ha/year.
In case there are targeted managment / inputs leading to SOC improvement involved, applicable SOC Framework Methodology approaches may be allowed.
Support Info - SOC sequestration component will be excluded from the issuance of Planned Emission Reductions

state_nodes.description: Project meets all requirements for this methodology to be applicable for the calculation of CO2 removal units from the project.
Project Design can begin.
Determine the modelling units.
Each modelling unit area has homogeneous charcteristics in growth patterns, silvicultural treatment and planting date.
Modelling units determined.
Forest Inventory has been completed.
The process of a forest inventory is documented clearly and can be easily replicated.
The forest inventories follow the guidelines located in the BioCarbon Fund sourcebook.

The number of sample plots of a forest inventory shall be sufficient to meet a MU precision with a maximum error of ±20% at a 90% confidence interval. Where the error is above 20%, the additional difference shall be deducted. For example. A forest inventory determined the mean 'Stem volume' of a MU at 100 m3/ha with an error of 23%. The error is 3% higher than required: 3% * 100 m3/ha = 3 m3/ha. The mean 'Stem volume' which can be accounted for is: 100 - 3 = 97 m3/ha.
Growth models of the MU confirmed by the results of MU specific forest inventories.
Carbon pool calculation can begin.
supporting_info: Positive leakage and market leakage are not accounted for under this methodology.
Harvested wood (timber & energy wood) as well as litter & lying deadwood are excluded.
More default values for 'tree biomass' are in the IPCC Guidelines for National GHG Inventories
More default values for 'non-tree biomass' are in the IPCC Guidelines for National GHG Inventories

If preferred, project develoFutures may also select the more precise IPCC defaults when available in place of the provided defaults for factors relating to tree and non- tree biomass with no justification required.

state_nodes.description: Selection and justification of The Baseline scenario can begin.
Baseline determination starting point.
Eligible planting area has been stratified according to its vegetation types (grassland, shrubland, etc.).
For each of these strata, scientifically based project-specific, regional or national default values were found which state 'tree' and 'non-tree' biomass of these vegetation types.
supporting_info: Default values from the IPCC shall only be used if no other values are available.

state_nodes.description: Baseline calculations can begin.
Calculate tree biomass for each strata.
supporting_info: The BEF can be age-dependent and thus change over time.
In cases where a Biomass Conversion and Expansion Factor (BCEF) is used, the factors BEF and Wood Density are both integrated.
Deadwood differs in it Wood Density, BEF and Root to Shoot ratio from the living tree.
Scientific sources can relate to a relative figure or a calculative figure.

state_nodes.description: Calculate above ground biomass.
supporting_info: C to CO2 default value is 44/12.
Carbon Fraction default value is 0.5.
Biomass Expansion Factor [] x Stem Volume [m^3] x Wood Density [tdm/m^3] * Carbon Fraction [tC/tdm] * C to CO2 Factor [tCO2/tC] = Above Ground Biomass [tCO2e]

state_nodes.description: Calculate below ground biomass.
supporting_info: Above Ground Biomass [tCO2e] x Root to Shoot Ratio [] = Below Ground Biomass [tCO2e]

state_nodes.description: Calculate non-tree biomass for each strata. Non-tree biomass [tdm] x Carbon Fraction [tC/tdm] * C to CO2 Factor [tCO2/tC] = Non-tree biomass [tCO2e]
Calculate soil organic carbon for each strata. (Optional)
supporting_info: Projects complying with this methodology's requirements may use the Yardstick integration Tool in order to account for SOC. The tool assists you in measuring the change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the planting of forests and applies to soils on planting areas only. Once a project has undergone a successful design certification, credits calculated using this tool may be issued following a successful performance certification. Projects shall not issue Futures resulting from this calculation tool.

state_nodes.description: Confirmed that a conservative approach was followed when performing calculations.
supporting_info: The CO2 removal was not exaggerated. The Baseline and Leakage were not underestimated.

state_nodes.description: Biomass calculation completed.
Determine the Baseline for each Modelling Unit (MU) level
supporting_info: Use the following formula: Baseline MU,t [tCO2/ha] = Baseline Eligible planting area [tCO2] ÷ Eligible planting area [ha]

state_nodes.description: Baseline has been determined and was not underestimated.
supporting_info: The Baseline is not subject to monitoring or reassessment at the time of renewal of the credit period.

state_nodes.description: Was The Baseline determined in the eligible planting area just prior to the start date of the project? (within 90 days)
The baseline document is completed and ready for submission.
Determined the silivicultural method for each Modelling Unit.
If the silvicultural method is 'rotation forestry', the long- term CO2 removal is the average 'tree biomass' of a MU during the planting start and the end of the crediting period.
If the silvicultural method is selective harvesting or conservation forest, the long-term CO2 removal is determined by the 'tree biomass' when a MU reaches its equilibrium.
supporting_info: If the 'tree biomass' is still increasing at the end of the crediting period, the long-term CO2 removal is determined by the 'tree biomass' of a MU in the year the crediting period ends.

state_nodes.description: CO2-removal calculation start
Calculate tree biomass for each MU.
supporting_info: Where stem volume is predicted/measured at the end of the crediting period.

The following default factors shall be used when no rigorous scientific information is available: a. For the parameters of CO2 removal: i. 0.3 [tdm/m3] Wood density ii. 1.1 [ ] BEF iii. 0.2 [ ] Root-to-Shoot ratio for 'tree biomass'

state_nodes.description: Calculate above ground biomass.
supporting_info: Biomass Expansion Factor [] x Stem Volume [m^3] x Wood Density [tdm/m^3] * Carbon Fraction [tC/tdm] * C to CO2 Factor [tCO2/tC] = Above Ground Biomass [tCO2e]

state_nodes.description: Calculate below ground biomass.
supporting_info: Above Ground Biomass [tCO2e] x Root to Shoot Ratio [] = Below Ground Biomass [tCO2e]

state_nodes.description: Calculate CO2 removal of a MU / year.
Calculate long-term CO2 removal units
state_nodes.supporting_info: Sum: T=1 -> T CRMU,long_term = (∑T CR MU,t) / T

state_nodes.description: The yearly CO2 removal is determined at the level of MU during the crediting period.
For every MU a growth-model and conversion factors have been determined using the standardized procedure.
The conversion factors allow the conversion of the 'Stem volume'.
supporting_info: The conversion factors are not subject to monitoring.
Normally measured in cubic meters [m3] during the forest inventories, to 'tree biomass' with the unit tCO2. For the conversion, the standardized procedure was used.

state_nodes.description: Is existing 'tree biomass' from the carbon stock of The Baseline that is not removed is reflected in the growth model?
Is a realistic survival rate is reflected in the growth models?
Was the long term CO2 removal was determined based on the silvicultural method applied / envisioned?
CO2 Removal document completed.
Calculate soil organic carbon for each MU. (Optional)
supporting_info: Projects complying with this methodology's requirements may use the Yardstick integration Tool in order to account for SOC. The tool assists you in measuring the change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the planting of forests and applies to soils on planting areas only. Once a project has undergone a successful design certification, credits calculated using this tool may be issued following a successful performance certification. Projects shall not issue Futures resulting from this calculation tool.

state_nodes.description: Other Emissions calculations start.
supporting_info: Combustion of fossil fuel - CO2 and Non-CO2 green-house-gas emissions caused by the use of fossil fuel from project activities (flights, management operations, etc.) are insignificant and may therefore be neglected.
N-fixing trees, CO2 and Non-CO2 green-house-gas emissions caused by the use of N-fixing species may be conservatively assumed to be zero.

state_nodes.description: Calculate - Site preparation - Where existing 'tree' and 'non-tree' biomass of the Baseline is burned for the purpose of land preparation, an additional 10% of the Baseline has been deducted.
state_nodes.supporting_info: This is to account for N2O and CH4 emissions that are released during the burning process. Based on project specific data, a lower percentage may be applied when justified based on relevant literature and other sources.

state_nodes.description: Calculate - Fertiliser - 0.005 tCO2 per kg of nitrogen (N) fertiliser has been deducted.
state_nodes.supporting_info: No differentiation is made between synthetic and organic fertiliser. Based on project specific data, a lower value may be applied when justified based on relevant literature and other sources.

state_nodes.description: Other Emissions document completed.
Leakage calculation start point.
supporting_info: The following default factors shall be used when no rigorous scientific information is available: 0.7 [tdm/m3] Wood density 3.5[]BEF 0.8 [ ] Root-to-Shoot ratio for 'tree biomass' 4.0[ ] Root-to-Shoot ratio for 'non-tree biomass'
General leakage formula: Leakage MU,t [tCO2/ha] = Leakage Project area [tCO2] ÷ Eligible planting area [ha]

Leakage is deducted in the first year (t=1). With the application of formulas, all potential Leakage caused by a project within its crediting period is accounted for in year 1. Thus, the parameter is not subject to monitoring.

state_nodes.description: Caculate CO2 stock for collection of wood (for firewood, charcoal, etc.).
Caculate CO2 stock for timber harvesting.
Caculate CO2 stock for agriculture (crop cultivation, shrimp cultivation, etc.)
Determine % activity-shift using a credible etimation or representative survey.
Calculate leakage emissions.
supporting_info: Use the following formula: Leakage Project area [tCO2] = Area [ha] x % of activity-shift [%] x CO2-stock [tCO2/ha]

state_nodes.description: Calculate Livestock CO2 stock [tCO2/ha], displaced heads [head], and grazing capacity [ha/head] using a credible estimation or representative survey.
Calculate leakage emissions.
supporting_info: Use the following formula: Leakage Project area [tCO2] = Displaced heads [head] x Grazing capacity [ha/head] x CO2- stock [tCO2/ha]

state_nodes.description: Leakage document completed.
Carbon pool calculations completed
Carbon performance document start.
Document Shortfalls of the project.
Document how you propose to make the project compliant again, latest in 5 years.
Carbon performance document completed.
Submit Carbon performance document.
Submit Leakage document.
Submit CO2 Removal document.
Submit Other Emissions document.
Submit Baseline document.
Demonstrate additionality - the project developer shall demonstrate additionality as per the requirements defined in Land Use & Forests Activity Requirements (LINK).
Applicability documents submitted.
Project documents and proposal accepted/verified by natureblocks or Ecora.
Planned or Verified offsets generated.
